for Statement

The for statement is similar to the while statement, but more complex.
The syntax is as follows:
for(Clause 1;Clause 2;Clause 3)     statement or block
Here, in Clause 1, you specify the expression you want to execute before entering the loop. You can also perform variable declarations here, and variables declared here are considered valid throughout the loop (they are deleted upon exiting the loop). It can also be omitted.

In Clause 2, you specify the conditional expression. While this conditional expression is true, the statement or block is executed repeatedly. If omitted, it is always considered true.

In Clause 3, you specify the expression you want to execute at the end of the statement or block. It can also be omitted.

In terms of operation:
(1) First, execute Clause 1
(2) Evaluate Clause 2; if false, the statement or block is not evaluated and the loop ends
(3) Execute the statement or block
(4) Execute Clause 3
(5) Evaluate Clause 2; if false, exit the loop
(6) Repeat from (3)

If there is a break statement within the block, the loop is exited at that point. If there is a continue statement, it jumps to (4).


Example:
    var i,a=1;
    for(i=1;i<5;i++)
    {
        a*=i;
    }

    var i;
    for(i=0;i<10;i++)
    {
        if(obj[i]==0) continue; // i++ is executed even if continue is used
        if(obj[i]==1) break; // break exits immediately on the spot
        func(obj[i]);
    }
